results.title: TB trailer
results.brief_description: Points out that TB (tuberculosis) can be eradicated from Australia, if sufferers are found and cured. Urges that everyone, including older people, should have an annual chest X-ray.

results.title: Taxithi
results.creator_credit: Christina Heristanidis, Peter Tammer and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Taxithi, which means “journey” in Greek, examines an integral but often overlooked and under-represented part of Australian contemporary society: migrant culture. Melbourne filmmaker Christina Heristanidis turns the camera on her immediate surroundings, specifically, her Greek parents, their culture and history in order to understand and appreciate their Greek-Australianess. As well as capturing her parents relaxing at home or attending their social clubs, Christina also accompanies them on a road trip they take to the country with their community of friends. The manner in which they deal with encounters and express themselves through their culture (singing, dancing, communal happiness) as a group evokes the film’s central theme: that migrants bring their culture with them, that culture continues through people rather than solely through place and that this shared culture enables community, solace and optimism. In “Taxithi”, the camera becomes an extension of the filmmaker that often turns onto the filmmaker herself and her own relations with her parents. Never short of humour, warmth and goodwill, “Taxithi” is a special documentary that reveals the richness and history that lies below the surface of everyday Australian suburbia.

results.title: Taxi!
results.creator_credit: Barry Greenwald, Arthur Hammond and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In any large city one of the most visible and, at the same time, anonymous characters is the taxi driver. Taxi! takes an absorbing, entertaining and sometimes comical look at a world few of us are familiar with. The filmmaker, a former cabbie, has produced a unique documentary study of the drivers, fleet operators and dispatchers who are expected to deliver passengers, parcels, and even babies. Photographed by day and night, the film explores the realities of the taxi business, the economics, and life as witnessed from behind the steering wheel.

results.title: Taxi to Rumdoodle
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the hardy taxi to Rumdoodle, which takes passengers over the snow and ice to Mawson base from the airstrip at Rumdoodle in Antarctica. Shows how the car stands up to the cold weather, and rough conditions, saving the snow-cat and tractors for other work and maintaining speeds of 40-50 m.p.h. on sea ice. Shows the penguins, seals and huskies, typical scenery and the men of the A.N.A.R.E. at work at the base and on inland expeditions.

results.title: Taxi driver [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Michael Phillips, Julia Phillips and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Robert de Niro plays Travis Bickle, a Vietnam veteran who takes up driving a cab at night in New York City. The job brings him into contact with what he calls the “scum and sewerage, the pimps and pushers” of the city. He attempts to find redemption through love, first for the politically ambitious and sophisticated Betsy (Cybill Shepherd), and, when he is rejected, by rescuing a 12 year old prostitute (Jodie Foster) from her pimp. When love fails Travis, he is provoked into an act of savage violence as his judgement on the world. The film is infamous for having influenced American President Reagan’s would-be assassin John Hinkley, but it is more significant for portraying the paralyzing decay and resultant psycho-pathology of American urban life. Scripted by Paul Schrader, “Taxi Driver” is one of Scorsese’s masterworks. Cast also includes Harvey Keitel.

results.title: Taxi Driver
results.brief_description: Taxi Driver is one of the most iconic films of the 1970s. The savage story of a social misfit from screenwriter Paul Schrader is powerfully directed by Martin Scorsese, with compelling performances from Robert De Niro, Jodie Foster and Harvey Keitel.

constellations_other.name: Hell no, we won't go
constellations_other.description: The cultural, social, psychological and political effects of the Vietnam War have been explored through cinematic classics, musicals and comedies.

constellations_other.name: Reflecting duality and revealing new realities
constellations_other.description: The Toupie Fantoche relies on four prismatic mirrors to reflect changes in animation states.

constellations_other.name: Colour and creativity
constellations_other.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

recommendations.quote: De Niro’s Travis Bickle is one of the key figures of American cinema; the passage of his taxi through the grubby, smoky streets of the city – accompanied by the great composer Bernard Herrmann’s final score – are unforgettable.  So are his improvised monologues - "Are you talking to me?”

results.description:
Taxi Driver is one of the most iconic films of the 1970s. The savage story of a social misfit and Vietnam vet is brilliantly explored in Paul Schrader’s potent screenplay and Scorsese’s powerfully physical direction, with compelling performances from Jodie Foster and Harvey Keitel. Towering over all is the performance of Robert De Niro, whose obsession with porn and violence lead to the film’s powerful ironic climax.

Robert De Niro’s Travis Bickle is one of the key figures of American cinema; the passage of his taxi through the grubby, smoky streets of the city – accompanied by the great composer Bernard Herrmann’s final score – are unforgettable. So, too, are his improvised monologues in front of a mirror (“Are you talking to me?”).

Like Robert Altman’s Nashville, made the year before, the film alludes to the political assassinations of the 60s while turning the violence in another direction altogether and, like no film before it, explores the world of teenage prostitution – Jodie Foster as a 12-year-old prostitute and Harvey Keitel as her pimp – with an unblinking eye. The New York depicted here evokes the sordid nightmare of Midnight Cowboy rather than the clashing codes of family, religion and criminality Scorsese had explored in Mean Streets. The film’s Cannes Film Festival Palme d’Or confirmed the director’s status as an American master.
description_for_label:
Taxi Driver is one of the most iconic films of the 1970s. The savage story of a social misfit and Vietnam vet is brilliantly explored in Paul Schrader’s potent screenplay and Scorsese’s powerfully physical direction, with compelling performances from Jodie Foster and Harvey Keitel. Towering over all is the performance of Robert De Niro, whose obsession with porn and violence lead to the film’s powerful ironic climax.

Robert De Niro’s Travis Bickle is one of the key figures of American cinema; the passage of his taxi through the grubby, smoky streets of the city – accompanied by the great composer Bernard Herrmann’s final score – are unforgettable. So, too, are his improvised monologues in front of a mirror (“Are you talking to me?”).

Like Robert Altman’s Nashville, made the year before, the film alludes to the political assassinations of the 60s while turning the violence in another direction altogether and, like no film before it, explores the world of teenage prostitution – Jodie Foster as a 12-year-old prostitute and Harvey Keitel as her pimp – with an unblinking eye. The New York depicted here evokes the sordid nightmare of Midnight Cowboy rather than the clashing codes of family, religion and criminality Scorsese had explored in Mean Streets. The film’s Cannes Film Festival Palme d’Or confirmed the director’s status as an American master.

results.title: Taxi = Taksi
results.creator_credit: Arifin C Noer, Manu Sukmajaya and Raviman Film
results.brief_description: One of Arifin C. Noer’s well-known works, ‘Taksi’ is a social commentary about going against the establishment. Guyon, a philosophy graduate, decides to leave the comfort of his rich uncle’s house to become a taxi driver after two years of being unemployed. During one of his rounds, Guyon picks up an unwed mother on her way to a singing audition. She entrusts the baby with him and the two develop a friendship; she succeeds in the entertainment business but is drawn into a web of lies and posturing. The film swept all the major awards at the 1990 Citra Awards including Best Actor - Rano Karno. This, his first Citra Award, propelled Karno into mega-stardom in Indonesia. Cast also includes Meriam Bellina. In Indonesian with English subtitles that are sometimes hard to read.

results.title: Taxi
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The film shows the daily work of Jim McKenzie, a taxi driver from Perth in Western Australia. Jim lives five miles from the city with his wife and daughter. He owns his own cab and has been in the business for four years. The hours are long - but driving a cab means that a man is his own boss - which is imnportant to Jim McKenzie.
